column4: I am about to upgrade my hardware processor (Athalon 32 bit) and motherboard to get access to virtualization with a new AMD Athalon 64.  I want to just put the hard drive into the new machine.  I will use the same video card.  I am pretty sure that will work since the 32 bit architecture is available in the 64 bit version of the AMD Athalon 64.  What is the best way to get Ubuntu to update...
...to the 64 bit version... and can anyone see any issues I may face (first time updating hardware in a Linux environment)
if you go 32 > 64 bit , you need a fresh install
you can do a dist upgrade, but why do you want to change to 64 bit at all ?
can do also in 32
it's just the cpu that supports it or not, both 32 abd 64
so a socket a athlon ?
nah, is it running   any os at this time ?
Ubuntu  - it is what I am taking to you on
sudo apt-get install hwinfo pastebinit
hwinfo -vv | pastebinit
did  a simple hwinfo and piped it over to http://pastebin.com/f444b2de2
what are you looking for - I piped it to more also, so I could look at it
RAM?? I thought it used a specific amount of disk space?  I only have two gigs on this machine
it is a KV7-V(VIA KT600-8237)'
phoenix mother board
I have space for one more gig of memory
So you are proposing an ALL software virtualization? rather than the CPU calls??
I tried Wine which did not work and looked at Crossover - which did not look promising - so I decided to give virtualization a try - THOUGHT I had to upgrade to a CPU with calls to get it done
anm currently not running any virtual amchine
Oh - which version of Ubuntu : Karmic 9.10 vmlinuz-2.6.31-16-generic
and a AMD Athlon(tm) XP 2900+
I am more interested in getting Windows XP to run for myself - I have a proprietary product that I MUST access and nothing in Open Source to replace it
I should load virtual box OSE from the application library then??
